title-group.article-title: Users’ perceptions of the relative costs and benefits of 2D and 3D visual displays in discrete-event simulation

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Information Systems and Decision Sciences, Fairleigh Dickinson University, Canada
2Department of Management Science, Lancaster University Management School, UK

author-notes.corresp: Roger J Brooks, Department of Management Science, Lancaster University Management School, Lancaster, LA1 4YX, UK Email: roger.brooks@lancaster.ac.uk

fn.p: Ikpe Justice Akpan is full-time Visiting Assistant Professor of Information Systems and Decision Science, and Academic Programme Co-ordinator for the Bachelor of Science in International Business at Fairleigh Dickinson University, Vancouver Campus, Canada. He holds a BSc (Hons) in Economics from University of Calabar, an MSc in Software Development from Leeds Metropolitan University, UK and a PhD in Management Science (Operations Research) from Lancaster University Management School, UK. He also consults for private sector businesses on operations and process improvement, and resource optimization.

Roger J Brooks is a lecturer in the Management Science department at Lancaster University (UK). He has a BA (Hons) degree in mathematics from Oxford University (UK) and an MSc (Eng) and PhD in Operational Research from Birmingham University (UK). He is co-author with Stewart Robinson of a textbook on simulation, and one of the editors of a recent book on conceptual modeling for simulation. His areas of interest include conceptual modeling, impacts of aspects of the simulation process on project success, agent-based simulation and the simulation of networks.

abstract.p: The use of two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) visual displays for discrete-event simulation (DES) has become very popular within the simulation community in recent years. This paper presents results from surveys of users of 3D and 2D simulation applications regarding their views of the impact, benefits and drawbacks of 3D displays. The results indicate that 3D displays can often be more effective than 2D displays in communication, verification and validation, and experimentation. This can lead to a better project outcome with an improved understanding of the real system and a better solution for the decision maker. The main drawback is the additional cost, time and complexity of building the model. Potential implications for modeling in general are the importance of being able to relate the model to the real system and of involving the decision maker in the modeling process.
